As General Electric (GE) steps up efforts to cut costs and boost profits, the industrials giant may sell a stake in the industrial software unit that served as a linchpin of ex-CEO Jeff Immelt's "digital industrial" vision but proved a drag on GE stock.XNew chief executive John Flannery is contemplating expanded partnerships and the possible sale of some equity in the unit, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the business.Immelt — who bowed out of the Uber leadership race in a Sunday tweet — reportedly spent six years and poured more than $4 billion into efforts to infuse GE's core industrial businesses with technology. But revenue and returns fell short of expectations, and the Predix industrial software platform was dogged by problems this spring, according to Reuters.I have decided not to pursue a leadership position at Uber. I have immense respect for the company & founders — Travis, Garrett and Ryan.— Jeff Immelt (@JeffImmelt) August 27, 2017But those problems have now been fixed, the report added, and GE will focus on sales to existing customers in its energy, aviation and oil-and-gas businesses, while paring back sales efforts to new customers in other sectors.IBD'S TAKE: GE is a laggard among Dow stocks this year. But the Dow's top stock may be offering a new entry point."Our resources will go to our fastest-selling markets," GE Digital Chief Executive Officer Bill Ruh told Reuters in an interview.Additionally, to help investors better understand Predix and avoid double-counting, GE has redefined digital revenue to shut out certain hardware sales and emphasize "pure" software sales.As a result, GE officials now anticipate $12 billion in digital revenue in 2020 vs. $15 billion earlier.The Predix platform — a cloud-based operating system for what GE calls the industrial internet — outfits turbines, jet engines wind farms and medical equipment with data-collecting sensors and then analyzes that data to analyze performance, cut costs or create new businesses for GE customers.GE estimates the market could be worth $225 billion market by 2020.Shares were unchanged at 24.49 in morning trade on the stock market today. GE bounced off a fresh 23-month low set last week.The stock is down 22.5% year to date vs. a 10.5% gain for the Dow Jones industrial average as a whole.Conglomerate peers 3M (MMM), Siemens (SIEGY), Honeywell (HON), United Technologies (UTX) and Roper Technologies (ROP) were little changed.RELATED:How GE Could Become The Apple Of The Industrial InternetThis 'Celebrity CEO' May Be Able To Change Uber, But It's Not Tesla's MuskDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And Analysis

The stock market closed higher Thursday, with the three major indexes hitting new highs.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each climbed 0.6%. The Dow Jones industrial average also rose 0.6% as it added a bit of air above the 20,000 milestone. Small caps, which had been languishing, outperformed: The Russell 2000 added 1.4% and moved back above its 50-day moving average.Volume was lower, according to unconfirmed data. Shares rose 2.6%.Medical and enterprise software were part of the tech groups in the top 10. Others were technology services and hardware manufacturers.But some defensive groups also led, including dairy products, meat products and discount stores. Earlier this week, Dollar General (DG) announced it will open 1,000 stores and two distribution centers.Steel was the day's top-performing industry group. Steel makers are among the industries most likely to benefit from trade, tax and fiscal plans by the White House.After the close, Ubiquity Networks (UBNT) fell sharply after the company announced quarterly results. The building products company said it earned adjusted profit of 23 cents a share, above expectations. Sales climbed 19% to $550 million. The stock had the highest relative volume in today's trading.But GrubHub (GRUB) continued to sink, falling 4% more and closing below its 50-day line. Specialty drugmaker Shire (SHPG) reported mixed results for its treatment for premature infants Thursday, sending its stock up.The phase-two study treated babies born at 23 to 27 weeks with Shire's insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) protein replacement, SHP607. The study didn't meet its primary endpoint of improving retina damage (retinopathy), but it did bring a 53% reduction in the incidence of the lung disease severe bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) and a 44% reduction in severe intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), a type of brain injury, compared with the control group.Shire said this warranted further testing."For severe complications related to the lung and brain, there are no approved treatment options, and these data support our commitment to further investigate the potential systemic benefits of SHP607 in this population where the unmet patient need is substantial," Shire R&D head Philip Vickers said in a statement.Shire stock ended up 1.9% at 184.04 on the stock market today, regaining its 50-day line.Leerink analyst Jason Gerberry noted that Shire referred to the lung and brain results as "clinically relevant" rather than "statistically significant," suggesting that the study was too small (121 infants total) to achieve significance for those endpoints. Shire will likely design its phase-three trial around this after consulting with the FDA, he wrote."With Shire now focusing on BPD and brain injury as primary endpoints, we believe the drug, if successfully developed, would continue to be positioned as a prophylactic agent in extremely premature babies," Gerberry wrote in his research note. "Shire estimates 60,000 babies are born prematurely globally with complications that include ROP (retinopathy of prematurity), BPD, and IVH," adding that he saw the market opportunity as largely unchanged.

The managers of $2.1 billion Columbia Mid Cap Growth Fund spun their wheels a bit in a difficult third quarter, but have kept their mutual fund on course. After outperforming the broad stock market and peer group tracked by Morningstar in the first and second quarters, the mutual fund lagged its peers in Q3. Some of that underperformance came from holdings in the energy sector.To cope, the fund has cut its energy weighting. It also saw energy holdings lose value. Its energy weighting of 1.56% as of Sept. 30 was more than 5 percentage points lower than a year earlier.In the case of trims, proceeds were recycled into stocks where the managers see better risk-reward opportunities for investors, says lead manager George Myers. "We invest in growth companies, but we aren't willing to overpay," Myers said.The approach has worked long-term as well as recently. The fund's 7.09% gain this year going into Tuesday topped 94% of its peers. The S&P 500 was up 3.27%.The fund carries a B+ 36-month Performance Rating from IBD, having performed among the top 20% of all mutual funds in that period.One stock they added to in Q3 was Signature Bank (SBNY), which is on IBD's Leaderboard. "We like this bank because, unlike big bank competitors, they offer customers a single point of contact," Myers said. "You don't get passed from one person to another. And the bank continues to take market share."Myers said the bank's pay package attracts talented employees, who bring their books of business.And Signature stands to benefit from any Federal Reserve interest rate hike.All-Weather StocksThe fund aims for growth stocks that are able to grow earnings no matter where we are in an economic cycle. To do that, a company needs a unique or at least superior product or service."For example, higher interest rates won't impact people's need to buy products from Incyte (INCY), the oncology (and rheumatoid arthritis) company," Myers said.The managers like the prospects for Incyte to build on revenue from new products in addition to its cancer treatment Jakafi. It is working to develop a cancer immunotherapy. And Myers says tests have been promising for a rheumatoid arthritis drug it is developing in a partnership with Eli Lilly (LLY)."We think Incyte's product is superior to (AbbVie (ABBV)'s) Humira, which sells for north of $15 billion globally," he said.LinkedIn (LNKD) is another stock that the managers like. "Our long-term thesis is that the talent solution segment, which is 60% of the business, will be better than people expect," said co-manager Brian Neigut. "The marketing solution segment, which was under pressure in 2015, will also continue to do better than Wall Street expects based on new product updates and ancillary products."Roper Technologies (ROP) is another favorite that the fund shifted money into. Co-manager William Chamberlain likes the company's knack for making accretive acquisitions such as legal software firm Aderant, in October. He also likes its wide variety of products.Chamberlain calls Roper an industrial firm that he increasingly thinks of as a tech stock.Ultimate Software Group (ULTI) is another fund favorite. The company benefits from an ongoing shift of payroll services to the cloud. "In 2016 we expect accelerating revenue growth, which will set them apart from many other tech companies, Myers said.

Aggressive growth investors know that betting against the the stock market trendis a bad idea.Yet sometimes aggressive investors will snub a fine-performing sector because it just doesn't sound growthy enough.This too is a bad idea. When the market is rewarding conservative names, savvy investors adjust.Consider four stocks from the Diversified Operations industry group. The names will prompt groans from aggressive investors. But get past the initial emotions. These stocks are outperforming the market.Diversified manufacturer 3M (NYSE:MMM) has gained 24% since mid-October, when the market pegged a short-term bottom. (During the same period, the major indexes gained 12% to 14%.) Big-cap 3M grew earnings 11% to 15% in the past four quarters. The last time the company delivered double-digit earnings in any quarter was in 2010.Pretax margin has stayed in a 20% to 23% range for at least nine years.The strong U.S. dollar could provide some headwinds for 3M. In Q3, 3M estimates that currency effects decreased quarterly income by $10 million.The company has shifted strategies since Inge Thulin became CEO in 2012. Thulin has increased spending on research and development and is pushing international growth.Honeywell (NYSE:HON), also a big cap, gained 20% from mid-October to now. Earnings growth has accelerated from 6% to 8% and 19% in recent quarters. Pretax margin in 2013 was 14%, the best in at least nine years.CEO David Cote said in a recent news release that Honeywell can deliver higher organic growth and expand margins in 2015 despite "only modest GDP growth in most regions around the world."Carlisle Companies (NYSE:CSL), a midcap, rose 19% since mid-October. Quarterly earnings grew 19%, 17%, 16% and, most recently, 28%. Revenue growth was 13% in Q3, the best in 11 quarters.Carlisle jacked up sales outside the U.S. from 12% in 2009 to 23% in 2013. The company has been growing through acquisitions.Roper Industries (NYSE:ROP) gained 14% since mid-October, narrowly topping the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq. Quarterly earnings growth dropped to 9% in Q3, ending a long streak of double-digit growth.All four stocks have Composite Ratings of 92 or better.The stocks also are housed in IBD's Miscellaneous sector, which was No. 1 among 33 sectors in Tuesday's IBD.Of the four stocks, three are extended from proper buy zones. Carlisle, though, appears to be working on a flat base and has found support at the 50-day moving average. The potential buy point is 91.99.Honeywell and Roper are barely extended from first-stage bases.Given the moderate growth these stocks offer, investors who play the conservative stocks should lower their price targets and lower their cut-loss figure.
Teachers use the Socratic method to challenge students to probe critical topics. At Roper Industries, it contributes to a culture of inquiry.

Brian Jellison embraces what he calls "the Socratic learning model" to spark disciplined and rigorous discussions about the business. Jellison is chairman, president and chief executive of Roper Industries (ROP), a Sarasota, Fla.-based diversified technology company with roughly 10,000 employees. Its products and services range from medical imaging equipment to energy systems and controls to software for a variety of end users.

Jellison, who joined Roper in 2001 as president and CEO after 26 years at Ingersoll-Rand (IR), strives to maintain open channels of communication between the senior leadership team and key managers throughout the company. Managers report their numbers every month in one-on-one meetings with top executives. They also convene with Roper's senior executives every quarter for a more comprehensive, four-hour analysis of their business operation.

"During this quarterly review process, they tell us about hot issues they're facing, competitive threats and other strategic matters," Jellison explained. Applying Socratic learning principles, Jellison and other senior executives pose questions to engage managers in a more searching dialogue.

Instead of lecturing someone on the need to hit certain numbers, for example, Jellison might ask, "How are you going to achieve this ratio?" Inviting managers to share their tactics often leads to richer, more rewarding discussions.
Two Listening Tips
Harnessing the Socratic method requires rapt attentiveness. Jellison, 68, credits mentors early in his career for teaching him the value of listening.
"I've developed a set of principles that have served me well," he said. "First, listen with the intent to learn. And second, understand before you try to influence."

As CEO, Jellison seeks to create a learning organization in which rising stars gain tools to sharpen their communication skills. At management meetings, he likes to reinforce aspects of effective leadership.

"We challenge our internal leaders — we really have about 40 CEOs here — to read (Stephen) Covey's books and gain insights into what it takes to lead," Jellison said. Covey is the author of "Seven Habits of Highly Effective People."

"In our meetings, we often go back to about 20 slides that cover what we call 'the leadership dilemma,'" Jellison said. For instance, Jellison might highlight the relationship between intensity and consensus as it affects decision-making and leadership.

"With high consensus with low intensity, you wind up with vacuous beliefs," he said. "With low consensus and low intensity, your competitors will control you. But when you have high intensity and high consensus, you get a strong culture."

Another aspect of leadership that Jellison often shares with his managers is the tension between control and innovation. True innovation occurs when individuals take measured risks and engage in free-flowing intellectual exploration. But some organizations stifle innovation by exerting too much control over employees.

"If you give people more freedom, you learn more from them," Jellison said. "The more you try to control them, the less influence you have."Teachers use the Socratic method to challenge students to probe critical topics. Stocks jumped out of the starting gates Monday, after an accord of sorts between the eurozone and Greece brushed global markets with a bit of optimism.

The Nasdaq pulled up 1.3% in early action. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.1% and the S&P 500 rose 1%. Volume was mixed, with early readings showing trade up 10% on the Nasdaq and down 2% on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Friday.

The stock market today opened on an up note after eurozone creditors struck a deal with Greece that may or may not open the door to bailout funds. The deal requires Greece's government to put in place by Wednesday pension reforms and tax increases, both of which were refused by Greek voters in a July 5 referendum. The deal also makes $10 billion available immediately to shore up Greece's faltering banks, but requires the government to privatize a $55 billion portfolio of assets — most of the proceeds from which will go to repay debt and recapitalize weakened banks. Greece's banks and stock market remain closed as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras goes home to attempt to convince his government to go along with the plan in order to hang in the euro currency bloc. Greece faces a $4.6 billion debt deadline to the European Central Bank on July 20.
Europe's top indexes had eased slightly from their early highs, with the CAC-40 in Paris up 1.8% and Frankfurt's DAX holding a 1% gain. The dollar climbed vs. the euro.

In U.S. stocks, airlines swept out to an early lead among industries, possibly owing to a 2% dive in oil prices. American Airlines Group (AAL) leapt 3%. Delta Air Lines (DAL), United Continental Holdings (UAL) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) gained 2% apiece.
GPS device leader Garmin (GRMN) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) each climbed 4%, running at the head of the Nasdaq 100.

At the head of the S&P 500, Marathon Petroleum (MPC) turned in a 9% gain at the start of the trade. Marathon's pipeline master limited partnership MPLX (MPLX) announced it would acquire another MLP, MarkWest Energy Partners (MWE), in a deal valued at $15.8 billion. MPLX shares dived 13%. MarkWest jumped 10%.
NewLink Genetics (NLNK) popped 4.6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The stock is 37% above a May 14 low and 19% below its April high, climbing the right side of a three-month consolidation.

A stronger U.S. dollar in the quarter is affecting diversified manufacturers Roper Industries (ROP) and Eaton (ETN), but both see promise in recent acquisitions.
Both also noted challenging macroeconomic conditions, but raised or affirmed full-year guidance.

Eaton, which makes truck drivetrains, hydraulics and aerospace components, reported adjusted first-quarter earnings of 84 cents per share, down 9% from a year ago, in part on the extra shares issued for $11.8 billion purchase of Cooper in November. That topped the 79-cents EPS analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expected.

Revenue climbed 34% to $5.31 billion, under forecasts for $5.4 billion. Core sales fell 5%, and currency effects accounted for another 1% reduction. But recent acquisitions — mainly Cooper — more than offset that.
Eaton reaffirmed guidance for 2013 EPS between $4.05 and $4.45, with analysts expecting $4.35.

In a statement, Eaton CEO Alexander Cutler said results in 2013 "will depend more on our execution than on global growth. We are off to a great start this year, with our execution driving stronger than expected results in the first quarter."
Eaton shares popped 3.5% intraday on the stock market today.

Roper, which makes medical imaging equipment and industrial control and monitoring tools, said adjusted first-quarter earnings per share climbed 17% to $1.27, 5 cents more than analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expected.
Revenue increased 4.2% to $740.7 million, though analysts were expecting $776.55 million.
It rang up record orders in the quarter, though its said conditions remained challenging.
Roper raised its full-year EPS guidance to a range of $5.76 to $5.94, from the earlier outlook of $5.60 to $5.82. Analysts expect $5.73 per share.

That new outlook factors in a boost from its $1 billion acquisition of Managed Health Care Associates, which provides equipment and services to pharmacies, acute-care facilities and other non-hospital medical settings. That deal should close this week, it said. The guidance also includes a negative currency impact of 5 cents per share.

General Electric (GE) announced it struck a deal with Clean Energy Fuels (CLNE) Tuesday to sell two liquefied natural gas systems as Clean Energy looks to expand its gas fueling stations.
Clean Energy — famous for its largest investor, former oil man T. Boone Pickens — is building a network of liquefied natural gas fueling stations across the country for long-haul truckers.

GE expects natural gas liquefying equipment to become a $1 billion market over the next five years, according to Mike Hosford, general manager of unconventional resources for GE Oil & Gas, in a Reuters article.
GE shares rose 0.3% to 20.73 in after-hours trading, while Clean Energy shares rose 0.7% to 12.35.

General Electric's MicroLNG plants will be able to provide liquefied natural gas for 70 fueling stations along interstates by the end of 2012. In 2013, Clean Energy hopes to have 150 filling stations.

With fracking projects in Appalachia and the Dakotas, natural gas has hit decades-low prices. The prices have prompted heavy duty truck parts maker Cummins (CMI) to make engines that use the affordable fuel.

"With an abundance of cleaner, more affordable natural gas here in the U.S., this is an important opportunity for GE to join Clean Energy in changing the way America drives," CEO Jeff Immelt said. "It's also a critical step in developing a natural gas-for-transportation fuel model that can be easily exported to other countries interested in exactly these kinds of breakthrough projects."
Clean Energy believes trucks using liquefied natural gas can save roughly 25% on their fuel costs. But the natgas engines are more expensive than regular engines.

Honeywell (HON) shares fell hard after a top executive for the diversified manufacturer said demand for its products in the U.S. and China has been better than expected the last couple of months, but that it's feeling a pinch as Europe's debt crisis and economic weakness lingers.

But it's hard to know whether investors reacted to the comments by CFO Dave Anderson or whether Honeywell fell in synch with the market, as the Dow crashed through its 200-day average, falling more than 220 points early on a disappointing employment report.

"The U.S. ... has really been terrific, and across the board really better than we expected," Anderson said. But, in Europe, "we're seeing the challenges now in terms of the commercial impact of the stresses showing up in our numbers."
In remarks at an industry event Friday morning, Anderson said his company is seeing improved demand from customers in the Middle Kingdom.
Regarding China, Anderson said: "We've seen some pickup ... a modest improvement, but not something that you would say is back to normal growth."

Shares for the Fortune 100 component, which makes products ranging from systems for cars and the aerospace industry to military equipment and automation systems for big buildings, fell 2.8% Friday morning to 54.12 after Anderson's comments.

Others in the Diversified Manufacturing group, including General Electric (GE), 3M (MMM) and United Technologies (UTX), earlier said they're seeing lower sales in China as the country's growth rate contracts.
GE slid 2.2% to 18.67 and 3M fell 1.4% to 83.21 in midday trade. United Tech was down 1.9% to 72.67.

Even top-rated companies in the Diversified Operations group felt the heat as Swiss electronics, valves, pipes and fire protection products maker Tyco (TYC), whose shares sport an 84 Relative Strength rating of a best-possible 99, fell 3.3% to 51.42. Roofing, tires and kitchen products maker Carlisle (CSL), with a Composite Rating of 91, fell 4% to 49.90, and energy and scientific systems company Roper Industries (ROP), which has a Composite Rating of 88, fell 3% to 98.19.
Honeywell's profit and sales growth have shrunk in the past year, partly because comparisons against strong growth numbers it put up post-recession are getting harder to match.
In the past five quarters, earnings per share grew 320%, 41%, 18%, 25% and 21% in its most recent quarter. Sales during that period grew 15%, 15%, 14%, 8% and just 7% last quarter.
